segments.text: According to him, the curriculum was now, quote, too modern, with not enough attention to algebra and the skillful use of slide rules.
As he proceeded to talk about what his generation
had used and needed, the youngsters began to shake their heads in disbelief because it was obvious that there was a generational gap between his thoughts and their aspirations.
Soon he called for the president of the senior class
to go with him to speak in opposition to the RISL recommendations.
That young man stood up and responded to the old timer that because the senior class had not discussed these matters
Neither he as class president nor any other individual could speak, quote, for the senior class.
In fact, he himself favored at least some of the changes, if not all.
Thus, the session ended, and the students walked away, sure, feeling confident,
that this gentleman was a bit out of touch with the current era.
Meanwhile, the former student leadership had moved quickly to lend their efforts to the recommendations.
Lindsay, Hervey, Wiris, all
In agreement.
About the need about.
The positive.
Potential positive results.
Other recommended changes.
Joined in a.
Minor revision.
To the agenda.
For their officers gathering.
They added a final.
topic, quote, other business, quote, to the listing of discussion matters.
Thus, as the meeting neared its conclusion and the men who had traveled from a wide variety of towns began to gather their bags,
President Lindsay said, oh, something to the effect, oh, there is one other item, other business.
Here is the background recommendations.
Do I hear any discussion?
Yes, there is a motion and a second.
No discussion.
All in favor say aye.
There are no nays.
Meeting adjourned.
As a few in the group tried to express their opposition,

Lindsay, Wyrus, and Hervey hurried down the hallway and handed Board Chairman Sterling Evans an official endorsement by the leadership of the former Student Association of the changes and the Board of Directors then officially approved
All of the recommended changes which had originated from the Aspirations Committee and its subunits, including RISL, except the change in the name.
These important modifications included the admission of women, voluntary
service in the Corps of Cadets, racial integration, gradual increase in admission requirements, and a broadening and deepening of the curriculum.
According to Vice President Hall, paragraph, according to Vice President Hall, Earl Rudder had been particularly disturbed
by the suggested change to Texas State University as the title of his alma mater.
He was particularly opposed to the dilution
to the elimination of any wording which would allow him and thousands of his contemporaries to identify their proud institution as A&M in some style or other.
Early in 1970, when I went as chairman of the library committee to seek increased funding
for the A&M Library.
Mr. Rutter's first response to that, on that point, was to ask, was to say, to note that, quote, y'all are always seeking more money for the library.
Do you think the students have read all the books we've already got?
Period, quote.
Then he promised that he would do the best he could to find extra dollars.
And perhaps for the only time in my acquaintance with him, I sought to continue
a conversation with him on other topics.
And ventured to note how much progress he had created at A&M and that only he, quote, could have done that.
With a smile, he inquired, why do you say that?
Then I noted that no critic could argue that he wasn't a Texan or an Aggie who had served in the Corps, had courageously made his mark
on behalf of the nation in World War II, was a hardworking husband, father, public servant, was not, quote, a fuddy-duddy PhD from somewhere else just passing through, period, quote.
And that he knew quote knew his way around Austin.
By acquaintance.
With.
Key individuals.
Like the president.
Governor.
Key legislators and others.
Period quote.
The man who often identified himself as the.
pot-bellied prexy of A&M, leaned back, smiled, and responded, oh, I never thought of any of that.
As we chuckled, he added an unexpected bit of advice.
If you guys had recommended
the name that LSU has, then you have gotten the approval of every recommendation you made.
When I, in confusion, asked about, quote, Louisiana State University as the title for a school in Texas, he shook his head in disbelief and noted that the title

of the land-grant school in Louisiana in the Pelican State is, quote, Louisiana State University and Agricultural and Mechanical College, quote, and that if we had proposed such nomenclature for his alma mater,
he and his contemporaries could have still, quote, called it A&M, and you youngsters gradually could have called it whatever you wanted, period, quote.
As the months quickly ensued, not quickly,
followed these changes, their results became more and more meaningful.
The board of directors, in their wisdom, modified the recommendation regarding women
so that females could enroll without restriction in the graduate and professional programs.
But at the undergraduate level, only if they were dependent of an A&M employee or student or
in some fuzzily worded phrase if they were seeking a degree which could best be obtained at A&M or something of that nature.
Nevertheless, the first semesters brought great change to the campus.
The enrollment began to grow rapidly.
As the pride and.
Satisfaction.
Of almost all.
A&M folks increased.
On the other hand, paragraph on the other hand.
A few determined.
conservatives began to continue their efforts to restrain the changes.
Perhaps the most determined of these
conservatives was an individual from Beaumont named Charlie Babcock who had relentlessly authored letters
Petitions, articles in newspapers, and other documents which he thought
would help keep his institution.
Mr. Babcock had served for many years as an officer
of the Beaumont A&M Club, a group then known for their, the regularity of their meetings and the ceaseless commitment of that group to their alma mater.

Because of the tenacity of Mr. Babcock's petitions, letters, and what seemed to be his unyielding admission that times were changing, I concluded that he must be an outdated demon with horns, a forked tail,
and a lack of understanding.
A few years later, as the Romont A&M Club prepared to celebrate the 50th anniversary of their never having missed a month during those decades for their meeting,
McQuarris asked if I would go with him to be the speaker on behalf of the A&M administration to those energetic Aggies in the largest city of the Golden Triangle.
As we were flying over in the A&M plane,
He mentioned that the group had planned to honor Mr. Babcock for his many years of service, although he had resigned his...
He had ended his longtime service to the club and had absented himself
since the initiation of the changes, which he thought would be devastatingly negative in their effect on A&M.
When we arrived at the Harvest Club, the site for the celebration on the grounds of the Southeast Texas State Fair
It seemed that six or seven hundred people were there, dressed appropriately for a good time.
And one of the club's leaders proudly announced, he's here, Mr. Babcock's here.
But yet he was unaware.
of the plan to honor him as the concluding highlight of the evening.
When that moment came, the master of ceremonies proudly invited Charlie Babcock
as the most devoted Aggie in the group to come to the platform.
That invitation followed many recollections of serious
as well as humorous events.
Perhaps the biggest chuckle had followed one speaker's mention that while there were women as full-time students at A&M, his wife had gone there
in the summers while he, as a veteran, was earning his degree.
And that although she had only earned 24 hours of credit, she, quote, met that she had more grade points than all the Kokonos brothers combined.
That's C-O-K-I-N-O-S, period, quote.
The loud applause and laughter which agreed with her pride came because that group of brothers had made their mark on the campus and in the community.
as devoted public servants, but they were not known as honor roll students.
Their immigrant father, when asked by a reporter during the World War,
How he felt about having quote so many sons on active duty.
Quote responded.
By saying that he wished he had twice as many sons as he did.
Because.
He would have been proud to to.
twice as much gratitude for their being able to come to America to grow up in America as they had enjoyed.
Period quote.
But as Charlie Babcock came to the stage I studied him
in surprise.
Instead of the tall, muscular, determined hulk that I expected, here was a small gentleman, less than average in weight and height, who seemed rather shy and reserved.
The crowd stood and cheered.
And then the MC, the master of ceremonies, put his arm on Mr. Babcock's shoulders and pulled out a plaque and turned to mention, to say how the group wanted to honor him
as the most diligent and energetic of all Aggies in the Beaumont club and that while they understood the integrity of his unyielding opposition to all of the changes
They hoped that now he would accept it.
Again, the crowd jumped to their feet as the little man stepped to the microphone and motioned for them to return to their seat, to be seated and in their applause.
He began to sob and then offered a truly unforgettable request, saying only, ladies and gentlemen, please forgive me.
I was wrong.
As we were returning on the plane, I asked Buchwaris to explain this man to me who had seemed to be a villain, but now obviously was a truly sensitive hero.
He noted that Babcock had graduated without any particular academic distinction.
gone to work for one of the refineries in the Beaumont area.
That he and his wife, a public school teacher, had two children.
But their daughter, unfortunately, had died suddenly one day in her junior high years from an unexpected heart ailment.
And he added, before he added, quote, and then their son, dash, quote, and I interrupted with, no, no, I hope not.
Before he added, their son died in a wreck going home to Beaumont.
during his sophomore year at A&M.
So I concluded my quick change of evaluation of this man with the heartfelt comment, I forgive him.
Ever since then,
when I attempt to offer examples of the depth of A&M of former student feelings and devotion.
I mention Mr. Babcock and that evening.
Following my muster remarks in Austin,
On April 21st, 1997, a tall man came up to me and indicated he wanted to give me, quote, the rest of the story, quote, about Charlie Babcock.
When I asked him his name, he told me, and now I can't remember, I'll have to fold that in later.
When I heard his identification, I asked for verification and then told him that he was the
finest hurdler that I had ever seen.
He inquired, what did I mean?
And I mentioned that in the spring of 1948, he won the district, regional, and state championships in the higher hurdles, setting a record in every race.
He wondered how I knew that, and I told him that he was a Beaumont Royal Purple.
at that time and that I, as an orange tiger,
